data.value: This section describes the available solvers that can be selected by the 'method' parameter. The default method is the
uses Brent's algorithm  to find a local minimum.  The algorithm uses inverse parabolic interpolation when possible to speed up convergence of the golden section method.
uses the golden section search technique . It uses analog of the bisection method to decrease the bracketed interval. It is usually preferable to use the
can perform bounded minimization  . It uses the Brent method to find a local minimum in the interval x1 < xopt < x2.
It may be useful to pass a custom minimization method, for example when using some library frontend to minimize_scalar. You can simply pass a callable as the
corresponds to any other parameters passed to
dict, which has its contents also passed as
parameters pair by pair.  The method shall return an
callable must be able to accept (and possibly ignore) arbitrary parameters; the set of parameters accepted by
may expand in future versions and then these parameters will be passed to the method. You can find an example in the scipy.optimize tutorial.
Objective function. Scalar function, must return a scalar.
defines the bracketing interval and can either have three items
which are assumed to be a starting interval for a downhill bracket search (see
); it doesn't always mean that the obtained solution will satisfy
is mandatory and must have two finite items corresponding to the optimization bounds.
Extra arguments passed to the objective function.
Type of solver.  Should be one of:
custom - a callable object (added in version 0.14.0), see below
Default is "Bounded" if bounds are provided and "Brent" otherwise. See the 'Notes' section for details of each solver.
Tolerance for termination. For detailed control, use solver-specific options.
The optimization result represented as a
a Boolean flag indicating if the optimizer exited successfully and
which describes the cause of the termination. See
for a description of other attributes.
